cards.Front: Define Lifestyle Medicine (per ACLM).
cards.Back: A medical specialty using therapeutic lifestyle interventions as a primary modality to treat chronic conditions (e.g., CVD, type 2 diabetes, obesity). Clinicians apply evidence‑based, whole‑person, prescriptive lifestyle change; when used intensively, these interventions can often reverse disease. Applying the six pillars also provides prevention.

cards.Front: List the six pillars of Lifestyle Medicine.
cards.Back:
1) Whole‑food, plant‑predominant eating pattern
2) Physical activity
3) Restorative sleep
4) Stress management
5) Avoidance of risky substances
6) Positive social connections

cards.Front: What are Intensive Therapeutic Lifestyle Change (ITLC) programs?
cards.Back: Multimodal, team‑based treatment programs that encourage dramatic changes in daily routine across diet, physical activity, sleep, and stress; typically group‑based visits, 60‑min sessions, 1–3×/week for 8–18 weeks (or shorter immersion). Evidence‑based programs include Pritikin, Ornish, and CHIP/Pivio.

cards.Front: Name the five core competency categories for prescribing lifestyle medicine (JAMA 2010).
cards.Back:
1) Leadership
2) Knowledge
3) Assessment skills
4) Management skills
5) Use of office & community support systems

cards.Front: Give 2 examples of actions under the Leadership competency.
cards.Back: Examples: Promote healthy behaviors as foundational to medical care; lead by example (personal healthy behaviors); create environments that support healthy behaviors at school, work, and home.

cards.Front: Give 3 examples of actions under the Knowledge competency.
cards.Back: Know the evidence that specific lifestyle changes affect health outcomes (e.g., smoking cessation and lung disease/cancer; exercise and breast cancer; fitness and CVD outcomes; plant‑based dietary patterns and BP/lipids/cancer). Know how engagement with patients/families affects behavior.

cards.Front: What are key Assessment skills in Lifestyle Medicine?
cards.Back: Assess biopsychosocial predispositions to behaviors and outcomes; assess readiness/willingness/ability to change (stages of change); take a lifestyle‑focused history/exam including lifestyle vital signs (tobacco, alcohol, diet, activity, BMI, stress, sleep, emotional well‑being); order/interpret tests to screen/diagnose/monitor lifestyle‑related disease.

cards.Front: What are examples of Management skills in LM?
cards.Back: Use nationally recognized practice guidelines; collaborate within interdisciplinary teams; co‑create prescriptions, SMART goals, and follow‑ups; track outcomes and adjust plans; integrate behavior‑change techniques and referrals to community programs.

cards.Front: What does ‘Use of office & community support systems’ entail?
cards.Back: Integrate systems that support behavior change: EMR prompts/vital signs, care pathways, group visits, health coaching, dietitian partnerships, and links to community resources (e.g., cooking classes, walking groups).

cards.Front: Define disease reversal (per the manual).
cards.Back: All laboratory markers or diagnostic tests of a disease are within normal range, without current use of any medications, and with no present signs or symptoms of disease.

cards.Front: How is disease ‘control’ different from ‘reversal’?
cards.Back: Control = improvement to accepted standard levels but without complete normalization; may occur with or without medications/interventions. Reversal = normalization without meds and no signs/symptoms.

cards.Front: Define disease remission.
cards.Back: Disappearance of the signs and symptoms of disease (can be temporary or permanent).

cards.Front: Define a whole‑food, plant‑predominant dietary pattern.
cards.Back: Mostly foods from plants (whole grains, vegetables, fruits, beans/legumes) with little to no animal products (dairy, meat, eggs).

cards.Front: Define Planetary Health (manual glossary).
cards.Back: A solutions‑oriented, transdisciplinary field and social movement focused on addressing impacts of human disruptions to Earth’s systems on human health and all life on Earth.

cards.Front: Which LM prescriptions support both personal and planetary health? Name examples.
cards.Back: Plant‑predominant diet reduces carbon/environmental footprint and provides antioxidants; physical activity as active transport lowers carbon footprint and bolsters immunity; stress management for climate anxiety/trauma; social connection for resilience; restorative sleep for immunity; avoidance of toxic substances to reduce pollutant load.

cards.Front: Who is often (incorrectly) credited with 'Let food be thy medicine...' and what’s the nuance?
cards.Back: The quote is often attributed to Hippocrates; best evidence indicates it’s not actually his, though he advocated healthy diet and physical activity to prevent/combat disease.

cards.Front: What did Thomas Edison famously say about the 'doctor of the future'?
cards.Back: He said the doctor would ‘interest his patients in the care of the human frame, in diet, and in the cause and prevention of disease.’

cards.Front: What was the Pritikin Longevity Center known for (1970s)?
cards.Back: A residential program using nutrition, exercise, and education to treat and reverse heart disease.

cards.Front: What did the John McDougall Program emphasize (1970s)?
cards.Back: Unlimited whole‑food, plant‑based diet, stress reduction, and exercise to treat/reverse disease.

cards.Front: What was shown in the Ornish Lifestyle Heart Trial (1980s)?
cards.Back: Regression of coronary artery stenosis at 1 year and continued improvement at 5 years using low‑fat vegetarian diet, stress management, exercise, and smoking cessation in small‑group settings emphasizing positive psychology/connectedness.

cards.Front: What long‑term work did Caldwell Esselstyn lead at Cleveland Clinic (1990s)?
cards.Back: A >20‑year longitudinal study on arresting/reversing heart disease in critically ill patients.

cards.Front: What is CHIP (now Pivio)?
cards.Back: An outpatient ITLC program promoting a whole‑food, plant‑based diet and exercise to prevent, treat, and reverse lifestyle‑related chronic disease.

cards.Front: What did the WHO (1990) report on diet and chronic disease address?
cards.Back: Links between poor diet quality/excess calories and chronic disease; included nutrient guidance on fats, proteins, carbohydrates, and salt.

cards.Front: Who authored the first comprehensive Lifestyle Medicine text (1990s)?
cards.Back: James Rippe authored a comprehensive medical text focused on Lifestyle Medicine.

cards.Front: When was ACLM founded and by whom?
cards.Back: Founded in early 2004 by John Kelly, MD, MPH (Loma Linda University), with a small group of providers.

cards.Front: How large is ACLM (as of 2023)?
cards.Back: More than 10,000 members and rapidly expanding.

cards.Front: What is ABLM and when was it organized?
cards.Back: American Board of Lifestyle Medicine (ABLM), organized in 2016 to develop a credible LM certification exam process.

cards.Front: What is IBLM and how does it relate to ABLM?
cards.Back: International Board of Lifestyle Medicine (IBLM), organized in 2016 to provide an international certification exam consistent with ABLM to ensure global standardization.

cards.Front: Distinguish Lifestyle Medicine vs Allopathic (Conventional) Medicine.
cards.Back: Allopathic medicine emphasizes diagnosing/treating disease with conventional evidence‑based measures (drugs/surgery). Lifestyle Medicine uses therapeutic lifestyle interventions as a primary modality; lifestyle approaches are often included in conventional guidelines as first‑line for chronic disease.

cards.Front: What is Preventive Medicine, and how does it overlap with LM?
cards.Back: Promotes preventive health to improve well‑being and prevent disease/disability/death at individual and population levels; many public health recommendations (exercise, dietary pattern, substance exposure) overlap with LM pillars.

cards.Front: Define Integrative Medicine (per table) in contrast to LM.
cards.Back: Brings conventional and complementary approaches together in a coordinated way; emphasizes multimodal interventions and treating the whole person; may utilize LM domains but differs in scope/approach.

cards.Front: Define Mind‑Body Medicine in contrast to LM.
cards.Back: Grounded in the mind‑body connection and self‑responsibility; utilizes practices like relaxation, imagery, meditation, yoga, biofeedback; overlaps with LM but is a distinct focus.

cards.Front: Define Functional Medicine in contrast to LM.
cards.Back: Individualized, patient‑centered approach focused on underlying causes using detailed genetic/biochemical/lifestyle data to direct personalized treatment; may use LM domains but differs in framework.

cards.Front: Define Complementary & Alternative Medicine (CAM) in contrast to LM.
cards.Back: Non‑mainstream approaches; ‘complementary’ when used with conventional care, ‘alternative’ when used in place of it; may use LM domains but differs in evidence pathways and scope.

cards.Front: Vignette: A 55‑year‑old with new T2D asks for ‘natural options first.’ What aligns with Lifestyle Medicine’s role?
cards.Back: Offer an LM‑first plan (dietary pattern change, physical activity, sleep, stress, substance avoidance, social support) with close follow‑up, while integrating guideline‑based monitoring; add medications as adjuncts if needed.

cards.Front: Vignette: Clinic wants to ‘do LM.’ First step to align team messages?
cards.Back: Hold an interdisciplinary meeting (physician, RD, PT/coach, etc.) to agree on LM pillars and specific counseling content (e.g., shared nutrition framework) before launching services.

cards.Front: Vignette: You’re designing LM workflow. Which vital signs/check‑ins belong at every visit?
cards.Back: Brief lifestyle ‘vital signs’: tobacco/alcohol use, dietary pattern, physical activity, BMI/weight, sleep, stress/emotional well‑being; with EMR prompts and referrals as needed.

cards.Front: Vignette: Your hospital asks for a program that catalyzes rapid change for severe cardiometabolic disease. Best LM‑aligned option?
cards.Back: Implement or refer to an ITLC program (e.g., Ornish/Pritikin/CHIP), then transition to maintenance/support phases.

cards.Front: Why is ‘lifestyle‑first’ prioritized in chronic lifestyle‑related disease?
cards.Back: Because evidence shows intensive lifestyle change can prevent, treat, and often reverse disease, with medications as adjuncts when appropriate.

cards.Front: Name 3 system‑level supports that enhance LM delivery.
cards.Back: Group visits; EMR prompts/templates for LM vital signs; partnerships with community resources (e.g., cooking classes, walking groups).

cards.Front: What is meant by ‘whole‑person’ in LM?
cards.Back: Plans integrate multiple domains (nutrition, activity, sleep, stress, social connection, substance avoidance) tailored to biopsychosocial context.

cards.Front: Leadership competency: give 3 ways clinicians can lead beyond the clinic.
cards.Back: Give grand rounds/community talks; advocate to policymakers for environments that support healthy behaviors; model healthy personal behaviors.

cards.Front: Assessment competency: what is meant by assessing ‘readiness, willingness, and ability’ to change?
cards.Back: Identify stage of change and practical barriers/facilitators; co‑create goals appropriate to current stage and capacity.

cards.Front: Management competency: why use nationally recognized guidelines in LM?
cards.Back: They anchor prescriptions to evidence‑based targets and safety thresholds while LM provides the therapeutic lifestyle framework.

cards.Front: Systems competency: why are group visits powerful in LM?
cards.Back: They increase access, peer support, and outcomes; allow longer education + brief 1:1 time; and improve satisfaction for patients/providers.

cards.Front: Name at least 5 ACLM presidents from early years to recent.
cards.Back: Examples: John Kelly, Marc Braman, Wayne Dysinger, Liana Lianov, David Katz, George Guthrie, Dexter Shurney, Cate Collings, Beth Frates.

cards.Front: What is the role of ABLM/IBLM in LM certification?
cards.Back: They provide standardized exams (ABLM US; IBLM international) to ensure core LM knowledge and skills.

cards.Front: Planetary: How does diet pillar contribute to planetary health?
cards.Back: Plant‑predominant dietary patterns reduce personal carbon/environmental footprints and provide antioxidants against pollutant‑related oxidative stress.

cards.Front: Planetary: How does the physical activity pillar support the planet?
cards.Back: Active transport (walking/cycling) reduces carbon footprint and supports immune health.

cards.Front: Planetary: How does ‘avoidance of risky substances’ relate to planetary health?
cards.Back: Reduces toxic exposures and overall pollutant load at an individual level.

cards.Front: Planetary: How can stress management & social connection help communities?
cards.Back: They address climate‑related anxiety/trauma and build resilience and mutual support structures.

cards.Front: Planetary: How does restorative sleep fit in?
cards.Back: Supports immune function and overall resilience, enabling sustained engagement in healthy/planet‑friendly behaviors.

cards.Front: Which field: ‘coordinated use of conventional and complementary approaches; multimodal; whole‑person’?
cards.Back: Integrative Medicine.

cards.Front: Which field: ‘focus on underlying causes using detailed genetic/biochemical/lifestyle data to direct personalized plans’?
cards.Back: Functional Medicine.

cards.Front: Which field: ‘mind‑body interconnection; practices include relaxation, imagery, meditation, yoga, biofeedback’?
cards.Back: Mind‑Body Medicine.

cards.Front: Which field: ‘population‑based prevention; immunizations, screening, bioterrorism preparedness’?
cards.Back: Preventive/Allopathic public health focus (not LM per se).

cards.Front: True or False: Lifestyle Medicine is primarily the promotion of vegetarianism as a cure for disease.
cards.Back: False. LM is evidence‑based therapeutic lifestyle interventions across multiple domains; medications/supplements are adjuncts as needed.

cards.Front: True or False: ‘There are few rigorous studies showing lifestyle change can treat or reverse disease.’
cards.Back: False. Decades of rigorous studies show intensive lifestyle changes can prevent, treat, and often reverse disease.

cards.Front: List 3 components of an LM office/community support system.
cards.Back: EMR prompts & templates; group visits; partnerships with RDs, health coaches, community programs.

cards.Front: Give examples of positive social connections as an LM target.
cards.Back: Family engagement, peer groups, group classes, community walking or cooking programs.

cards.Front: What is the aim of LM becoming the ‘foundation of healthcare’?
cards.Back: To integrate lifestyle‑first principles into all care pathways while collaborating with other specialties.
